questions.text: The following coronal section of the abdomen shows the relations of epiploic foramen. Which of the following structure forms its superior boundary as indicated in the image below?
Direct hernia arises from the Hesselbach's triangle, boundary of which is formed by the conjoint tendon. Identify the correct label showing the conjoint tendon
questions.solution:
(Ref: Gray’s 41/e p1080)

  • Label ‘C’ represent conjoint tendon



The conjoint tendon is formed by the lower fibres of the internal oblique and the lower part of the transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and the pectineal line. It is located right behind the superficial inguinal ring. It forms the medial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. The conjoint tendon reinforces the medial aspect of the Hesselbach’s triangle.


Hesselbach’s triangle, also referred to as the inguinal triangle, includes the following borders:

  • Medial: Lateral border rectus abdominis
  • Superolateral: inferior epigastric vessels
  • Inferior: inguinal ligament

Clinical significance of conjoint tendon:

Functionally, the conjoint tendon is integral to the mechanism that normally protects against a direct hernia arising through the weak posterior inguinal wall. The conjoint tendon physiologically supports the abdominal contents when increased intraabdominal stress occurs. A weakness in the conjoint tendon causes a type of direct herniation known as sports ernia or Bugosa herniation or Gill-Ogilvie hernia

questions.text: In which of the following, microvilli are not present?
questions.solution:
(Ref: Gray’s 40/e p17/19)

  • Microvilli are not present collecting duct
  • ‘Microvilli are finger-like cell surface extensions usually 0.1 mm in diameter and up to 2 mm long. When arranged in regular parallel series, they constitute a striated border, as typified by the absorptive surfaces of the epithelial enterocytes of the small intestine. When they are less regular, as in the gallbladder epithelium and proximal kidney tubules, the term brush border is used.’

choices.text: A. Linea alba B. Deep inguinal ring C. Conjoint tendon D. Anterior superior iliac spine
A. Arcuate line B. Superficial inguinal ring C. Inguinal ligament D. Posterior superior iliac spine
A. Linea alba B. Superficial inguinal ring C. Inguinal ligament D. Anterior superior iliac spine
A. Linea alba B. Deep inguinal ring C. Spermatic cord D. Anterior superior iliac spine

questions.text: In the following image of anterior abdominal wall, the correct match of the marked structures is:
questions.solution:
External Oblique - Insertion:

  • Anterior fibers: Forms a broad aponeurosis, terminates at linea alba
  • Lateral fibers: Inserts to anterior iliac spine & pubic tubercle, external lip of iliac crest

 

Inguinal ligament is formed by margin of aponeurosis of external oblique extending between anterior superior iliac spine & pubic tubercle

questions.text: Which of the following structure divides liver into various segments according to Couinaud's classification systems?
questions.solution:
• Portal vein divides liver into various segments according to Couinaud's classification system.
  • Current understanding of the functional anatomy of the liver is based on Couinaud's division of the liver into (subsequently nine, then later revised back to eight) functional segments, based upon the distribution of portal venous branches and the location of the hepatic veins in the parenchyma


  • The liver is divided into four portal sectors by the four main branches of the portal vein. These are right lateral, right medial, left medial and left lateral (sometimes the term posterior is used in place of lateral and anterior in place of medial). The three main hepatic veins lie between these sectors as intersectoral veins. These intersectoral planes are also called portal fissures (scissures). Each sector is sub-divided into segments (usually two) based on their supply by tertiary divisions of the vascular biliary (Glissonian) sheaths.

questions.text: Which of the following NOT present at the transpyloric level:
questions.solution:
• Transpyloric Plane passes through the tips of the ninth costal cartilages on the two sides that is, the point where the lateral margin of the rectus abdominis (linea semilunaris) crosses the costal margin.
  • The transpyloric plane is clinically notable because it passes through several important abdominal structures. These include:
    • Lumbar vertebra 1
    • Fundus of gall bladder
    • Neck of pancreas
    • Pancreatic body
    • Origins of the superior mesenteric artery from the aorta and portal vein
    • Left and right colic flexure
    • Left hilum of the kidney
    • Right hilum of the kidney
    • Root of the transverse mesocolon
    • Duodenojejunal flexure
    • 2nd part of the duodenum
    • Upper part of conus medullaris
    • Spleen

questions.text: Right gastroepiploic artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
• Gastroduodenal artery:
    • The gastroduodenal artery is a small blood vessel in the abdomen.
    • It supplies blood directly to the pylorus(distal part of the stomach) and proximal part of the duodenum, and indirectly to the pancreas via branches.
    • It arises from the common hepatic artery and terminates in a bifurcation, when it splits into the right gastroepiploic artery and the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery, which in turn has anterior and posterior branches.
  • These branches form a functional anastomosis with the inferior anterior and inferior posterior pancreaticoduodenal arteries from the superior mesenteric artery

questions.text: Appendices epiploicae is situated in:
questions.solution:
• Appendices epiploicae are adipose structures protruding from the serosal surface of the colon.
  • They can be seen with abdominal radiography and cross-sectional imaging if the colonic wall is surrounded by intraperitoneal contrast material, ascites, or blood. Normal appendices epiploicae appear as lobulated masses of pericolic fat, usually 2-5 cm long and 1-2 cm thick.
  • Their enlargement, deformity, or altered radiopacity may result from various pathologic processes that can originate locally or extend from adjacent viscera. In a series of 22 cases, appendices epiploicae were affected by spontaneous torsion and hemorrhagic infarct, calcification due to aseptic fat necrosis, primary or secondary inflammation, enlargement by lipomas or metastases, and incarceration in hernias.
  • Disorders of appendices epiploicae are often manifested by nonspecific clinical signs and symptoms (Eg. torsion is often mistaken for appendicitis or diverticulitis).
  • These entities should be included in the differential diagnosis of any unexplained abdominal pain or pericolic lesions in adults

questions.text: The helpful landmark in distinguishing the pyloric canal from the first part of the duodenum is:
questions.solution: The helpful landmark in distinguishing the pyloric canal from the first part of the duodenum are veins of Mayo

questions.text: What is the most common site for ectopic testis?
questions.solution:
• The most common site of ectopic testes is within the superficial inguinal pouch, which lies just inferior and medial to the superficial inguinal ring.
  • Ectopic testis must be differentiated from a retractile testis, both of which describe conditions wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position.
    • Ectopic testis is present outside the usual path of descent from the abdomen to the scrotum. Other ectopic sites include the femoral triangle, the root of the penis and perineum.
    • A retractile testis is present in the scrotum and occasionally jumps to lie in the inguinal canal.
    • An Ectopic testis is treated with Orchidopexy while a retractile testis requires no intervention as it resolves spontaneously.
  • The image below shows the possible ectopic sites of the testes :

choices.text: Support offered by right kidney and right colic flexure
Ligamentous attachments of liver capsule to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall
Hepatic veins attaching liver to the relatively fixed retroperitoneal inferior vena cava
Tone in the anterolateral abdominal muscles

questions.text: The most important anatomical structure that supports bulk of the liver in its position in right upper abdomen is:
questions.solution:
Inferior vena cava and the hepatic veins, especially right hepatic vein are the most important anatomical structures that support bulk of the Liver. The hepatic veins do not have an extra hepatic course, so the IVC is flush against the bulk of the liver.

Factors that support liver in its position in the right upper quadrant of abdomen are as follows:



Clinical Note:  After orthotropic liver transplantation, despite the absence of ligamentous structures, the liver remains within the right upper quadrant although it is more prone to torsion and rotation.

questions.text: All are branches of the internal iliac artery except?
questions.solution:
• Ovarian artery is a branch of the abdominal aorta.
  • Gonads develop in the abdomen region and gonadal arteries are branches of abdominal aorta.
  • As the gonads descend down to pelvic cavity, gonadal arteries become longer (Testicular > Ovarian in length).

choices.text: All of the duodenum is retroperitoneal
The 3rd part receives the bile duct
The 2nd part passes over the hilum of the right kidney
The 3rd part is crossed by the superior mesenteric artery

questions.text: Regarding the duodenum, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
• The duodenum is about 25 to 30 cm long (“twelve fingers' length”), C-shaped and is located in the upper abdomen at the level of L1-L3. The head of the pancreaslies in the C loop. It may be subdivided into four sections: superior part(D1), descending part(D2), horizontal part(D3) and ascending part(D4).
  • The superior part(D1) lies intraperitoneally. It is enlarged proximally (duodenal bulb). It is connected to the liver by the hepatoduodenal ligament.
  • The descending part and the rest of the duodenum lie retroperitoneally.
  • The common bile duct and the pancreatic duct unify to a conjoint duct at the hepatopancreatic ampulla (ampulla of Vater) and empties into the descending part(D2) of the duodenum. At the opening there is an elevation of the mucosa, the major duodenal papilla (Papilla of Vater).
  • There may be an accessory pancreatic duct which empties into the minor duodenal papilla (Papilla of Santorini)
  • Superior Mesenteric Artery(SMA) merges anterior to the uncinate process of the pancreas and crosses anterior to the third part of the duodenum
  • Ascending part(D4) of duodenum is attached to the back of the abdominal wall through the suspensory ligament of duodenum (Ligament of Treitz). Clinically the ligament of Treitz marks the border between the upper and lower gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A 21 year old man receives a penetrating knife wound in the abdomen & is injured in both the superior mesenteric artery & the vagus nerve. Which portion of the colon would most likely be impaired by this injury?
questions.solution:
Blood supply of gut:

  • Foregut: Coeliac trunk
  • Midgut: Superior Mesenteric Artery
  • Hindgut: Inferior Mesenteric Artery

Midgut structures:

The midgut consists of:

  1. Distal half of the duodenum
  2. Jejunum
  3. Ileum
  4. Cecum
  5. Ascending colon and
  6. Proximal half of the transverse colon

questions.text: Esophagus enters abdomen through:
questions.solution:
Esophageal hiatus(opening) is situated in the muscular part derived from the right crus of the diaphragm,at the level of T10 and is elliptical in shape.



  • A tip for remembering the vertebral levels: Vena cava has eight letters (T8), oesophagus has tens letters (T10), and aortic hiatus has twelve letters (T12).

questions.text: Dermatomal supply of the marked area is by:
questions.solution:
• Umbilicus (the marked area in figure) has T10 dermatomal supply.
  • The skin of anterior abdominal wall is innervated by ventral rami of T7 to T12 spinal nerves (lower 5 intercostal and subcostal nerve) and ventral rami of L1 (iliohypogastric nerve).
  • Lateral cutaneous branches of T7 to T11 supply lateral part of skin of anterior abdominal wall.
  • Anterior cutaneous branches of lower 5 intercostals (T7 to T11), subcostal (T12) and iliohypogastric (L1) supply paramedian region emerging through anterior wall of rectus sheath.
  • The dermatomal pattern is arranged in serial order; T10 near xiphoid process (epigastric pit), T10 at umbilicus level, the iliohypogastric (L1) 2-5 cm above the superficial ring and others at proportionate distance between them.

DERMATOMAL DISTRIBUTION

questions.text: Uvula vesicae in bladder is produced by which lobe of prostate:
questions.solution:
• In males, there is a bulging immediately posterior to the urethral orifice produced by median lobe of prostate, is called the vulva vesicae.
  • Ureters open at the lateral angles of the trigone and internal urethral orifice lies at the apex. Inter-ureteric ridge (Mercier’s bar) forms the base of trigone (line joining two ureteric orifices). Distance between ureteric orifices is 2.5 cm when empty and 5cm when bladder is distended.

(Ref : BDC 7th /e Vol.2 p. 407; AK Dutta Vol.1 p. 314)

questions.text: Source of blood to which of the following artery is through superior mesenteric artery:
questions.solution:
1. Superior mesenteric artery (midgut artery):
  • It arises from ventral surface of aorta at lower border of L1
  • Its branches are: -
  1. Inferior pancreatico-duodenal artery
  2. Middle colic artery
  3. Right colic artery
  4. Ileo-colic artery: - It divides into ascending and descending branches. Descending branches gives (a) anterior cecal artery, (b) posterior cecal artery, (c) ileal artery and (d) appendicular artery which provides a recurrent branch or recurrent appendicular artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from dorsal mesenteric (pancreatic) bud?
questions.solution:
• Pancreas develops from two pancreatic buds :
    1. Dorsal pancreatic bud:
      • It is larger and most of the pancreas is derived from it i.e. most of the head, and whole neck, body & tail.
    2. Ventral pancreatic bud:
      • It is smaller and forms lower part of the head of pancreas including uncinate process.
      • During 7th week of development, the ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds fuse to form a single pancreatic mass.
      • After the fusion of ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds, their ducts develop cross communications.
      • Final duct system is formed as below -
    1. Main pancreatic duct (Duct of Wirsung) is formed by the duct of ventral bud, distal part of duct of dorsal bud and an oblique communication between the two. The main pancreatic duct joins the bile duct to form hepatopancreatic ampulla that enters the 2nd part of duodenum at major duodenal papilla.
    2. Accessory pancreatic duct(Duct of Santorini) is formed by the proximal part of the duct of dorsal bud. It opens into 2nd part duodenum at minor duodenal papilla that is located 2 cm proximal (cranial) to major duodenal papilla.

(Ref: IB Singh 7th /ep. 283)

choices.text: Round ligament and transverse cervical ligament
Uterosacral ligament and transverse cervical ligament

questions.text: Ligaments holding the uterus in anteversion are:
questions.solution:
• The normal position of the uterus is one of the anteflexion and anteversion, i.e. the fundus and upper part of the body bent forward in relation to the long axis of the axis of the cervix (angle of anteflexion : normal 125o), while the organ thus leans forward as a whole from the vagina (angle of anteversion : Normal 90o).
  • Anteversion is maintained by:
    1. Forward pull on the uterine fundus by the traction of the round ligament of the uterus
    2. Backward pull on the cervix by the traction of uterosacral ligament.
    3. Intrinsic growth of the uterine musculature.

choices.text: It is directed backward and downward
Cystic artery usually pass behind it
Joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct

questions.text: All the following are characterestics of cystic duct except
questions.solution:
• The cystic duct attaches the gallbladder to the extrahepatic bile duct
  • Runs backward, downward, and to the left from the neck of the gall-bladder
  • Its point of insertion into the extrahepatic bile duct marks the division between the common hepatic duct and the common bile duct  
  • The cystic duct usually measures 4 cm in length 
  • It contains prominent concentric folds known as the spiral valves of Heister

choices.text: Fibrous tissue sheath around Bronchopulmonary segments
Fibrous tissue sheath around Bronchopulmonary segments
Condensation of connective tissue around the splenic vessels at hilum

questions.text: Valoean sheath refers to?
questions.solution: The bile duct, hepatic artery and portal vein are surrounded by a single fibrous sheath, called the Valoean sheath. This is an extension of the Glisson’s capsule, which becomes condensed as a sheath around the branches of the portal triad structures as they enter the liver parenchyma.

choices.text: Anterior to the ampulla of the vas deferens

questions.text: Regarding urinary bladder in the male, statement that is not true is:
questions.solution: In males, the posterior surface of bladder is related to rectovesical pouch, coils of intestine, seminal vesicles and terminations of vas deferens.

questions.text: Which of following is not a permanent mucosal fold?
questions.solution:
Temporary mucosal folds: (Obliterated by distension)

  1. Gastric rugae of stomach
  2. Longitudinal folds in mucosa of upper rectum and colon

Permanent mucosal folds:

  1. Plica circularis (valves of Kerckring) of small intestine
  2. Crescentic mucosal folds of cystic duct (spiral valve of Heister)
  3. Transverse (horizontal) rectal folds (Houston's valves or plica transversalis)
  4. Permanent longitudinal rectal columns or folds (found in lower rectum and anal canal)

questions.text: Which of the following vessels does not supply the anal canal?
questions.solution:
Anal canal is supplied by superior rectal, middle rectal, inferior rectal arteries and occasionally by median sacral artery.

  • The arterial supply to the anal canal is derived from terminal branches of the superior rectal artery, the inferior rectal branch of the pudendal artery and branches of the median sacral artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of mesorectal fascia?
questions.solution:
• Inferior rectal vein is not enclosed in mesorectal fascia.

Mesorectal Fascia

  • Mesorectum is enclosed by mesorectal fascia, which is derived from the visceral peritoneum, and is also known as visceral fascia of mesorectum, fascia propria of rectum or presacral wing of hypogastric sheath.
  • Upper rectum is derived from the embryological hind gut, it is surrounded by mesorectum.

Contents of Mesorectal fascia.

  • Superior rectal artery and its branches
  • Superior rectal vein and tributaries
  • Lymphatic vessels and nodes along superior rectal artery
  • Branches from inferior mesenteric plexus to innervate rectum
  • Loose adipose connective tissue down to the level of levator ani (pelvic floor)

(Ref: Grays 41/e p1147, 40/e p1151 – 1153)

questions.text: A midline abdominal incision below the umbilicus passes through all the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Also known as the laparotomy incision, or celiotomy, this is the most traditional of surgical incisions. Midline incisions may be small and applied anywhere on the vertical linea alba. However, they can also extend from the xiphoid process to the pubic bone.
  • This location is a mostly avascular plane and does not impose a great risk to the blood supply. There is rarely nerve damage in this region.
  • This incision generally provides the best visualization and intra-abdominal access and is commonly used for exploratory procedures and traumas

A midline incision will encounter the following layers of tissue:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous fatty layer (Camper's fascia)
  • Membranous fascia (Scarpa's)
  • Linea alba
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Preperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

choices.text: Bifurcates into the common iliac vessels on the body of L4
Gives rise to the testicular/ovarian artery above the renal artery
Arises from the thoracic aorta on passing anterior to the median arcuate ligament
Gives rise to the renal arteries at the level of T12

questions.text: True statement regarding abdominal aorta:

choices.text: Genital branch of Genito femoral nerve

questions.text: A patient comes to your clinic whom you operated for obstructed indirect Left Inguinal hernia one month ago. He says 'It has been over four months from the surgery and I still have much discomfort in the lower abdomen with pain radiating down my private parts.Inside of my thigh is numb and it burns when touched.Which nerve is most likely to be damaged ?
questions.solution:
• Ilioinguinal neuralgia is one of the most common causes of lower abdominal and pelvic pain.

Course of Ilioinguinal nerve:

  • The ilioinguinal nerve is a mixed nerve originating from the anterior rami of T12 and L1 nerve roots. It emerges near the lateral border of the psoas major muscle and goes inferior through the anterior abdominal wall, being sub-peritoneal and anterior to the quadratus lumborum muscle until it reaches the iliac crest.
  • Then the ilioinguinal nerve goes through the transverse abdominis and the internal oblique muscles. It becomes superficial by passing through the superficial inguinal ring anterior to the spermatic cord.

Innervation:

  1. Supplies Motor innervation to:
    1. Transverse abdominis and
    2. Internal oblique muscles.
  2. Carries sensory information from:
    • Anterior surface of the scrotum and root of the penis in males or labia majora and mons pubis in females
    • A small area of the upper anteromedial thigh.

Clinical Significance:

Because of its long course, entrapment or injury of the nerve after lower abdomen surgeries is common.

In Ilioinguinal neuralgia, patients can complain of burning pain, paresthesia, and abnormal sensation in the area supplied by the nerve -  over the lower abdomen that radiates to the genitalia and into the inner thigh.

choices.text: Is a remnant of Umbilical Artery
Is a remnant of Umbilical vein

questions.text: Median Umbilical fold:
questions.solution:
The internal surface of anterior abdominal wall contains elevations of peritoneum with free edges, called folds

Following folds are present in the midline:

  • Superior to the umbilicus:
    • A median fold, the falciform ligament. This contains the ligamentum teres, the obliterated umbilical vein.
    • Clinical significance: The umbilical vein is patent for some time after birth and may be used for exchange transfusion.
  • Inferior to the umbilicus, there are 5 folds:
    • The median umbilical fold is due to median umbilical ligament, the remnant of the urachus, which develops from the allantois. It attaches to the urinary bladder.
    • 2 medial umbilical folds formed by medial umbilical ligaments – the obliterated umbilical arteries.
    • 2 lateral umbilical folds – formed by the inferior epigastric vessels
